question.name: 11.2.1.2 Key Point
question.questiontext:
Key Point

Particularly important is the rule for differentiating powers of functions:

If \[y = x^n \hspace{2cm} \text{then} \hspace{2cm} \dfrac{dy}{dx} = nx^{n-1} \]
For example, if \(y = x^3\) then \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = 3x^2\).

Example

Use the table of derivatives to find \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} \) when \(y\) is given by

  1. \(7x\)
  2. \(14 \)
  3. \(5x^2\)
  4. \(4x^7\)

Solution

  1. We note that \(7x\) is of the form \(kx\) where \(k = 7\). Using the table we then have \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = 7\).
  2. Noting that \(14\) is a constant we see that \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = 0\).
  3. We see that \(5x^2\) is of the form \(kx^n\), with \(k = 5\) and \(n = 2\). The derivative, \(knx^{n-1}\), is then \(10x^1\), or more simply, \(10x\). So if \(y = 5x^2\), then \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = 10x\).
  4. We see that \(4x^7\) is of the form \(kx^n\), with \(k = 4\) and \(n = 7\). Hence the derivative, \( \dfrac{dy}{dx}\), is given by \(28x^6\).
